title: AI startups are turning their revenue into recruiting bait
summary:
A new trend has quickly emerged for AI startups that want to stand out from the rest: brag about revenue.
Unlike many AI startups now flexing their ARR, Sierra books its revenue through upfront contracts.
By contrast, many AI startups, especially those with more consumer-ish products or usage-based pricing, reach a public ARR figure by multiplying a good month’s revenue by 12.
“I think AI is a category where it’s relatively easy to make a demo and sort of win a popularity contest on social media,” he said.
Taylor is also already thinking about what happens when today’s crop of AI startups matures.

title: Sen. Warren presses Trump admin on potential AI bailout plans
summary:
is a news writer who covers the streaming wars, consumer tech, crypto, social media, and much more.
Posts from this author will be added to your daily email digest and your homepage feed.
Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) is pressing the Trump administration for more information on potential plans to “prop up” major AI companies with money from taxpayers.
She’s also seeking information about what kind of government assistance the administration plans to give OpenAI and other companies, as well as whether they think AMIC should apply to AI buildout.
Sacks and Kratsios have until December 1st, 2025, to reply.

title: With the Rise of AI, Cisco Sounds an Urgent Alarm About the Risks of Aging Tech
summary:
Aging digital infrastructure equipment like routers, network switches, and network-attached storage—has long posed a silent risk to organizations.
Dubbed “Resilient Infrastructure,” the initiative includes research and industry outreach as well as technical shifts in how Cisco manages its own legacy products.
Eventually, Cisco will go a step further to completely remove historic settings and interoperability options that are no longer considered safe.
“Infrastructure globally is aging, and that creates a ton of risk,” says Anthony Grieco, Cisco’s chief security and trust officer.
“The thing we’ve got to get across is this aging infrastructure wasn’t designed for today’s threat environments.

title: Perplexity brings its Comet browser to Android
summary:
Perplexity is launching its AI-powered browser on Android.
Comet launched on desktop for Perplexity Max subscribers in July before rolling it out more widely last month.
You can use voice mode on Comet’s Android app as well.
Image: PerplexityJust like Comet on desktop, you can use voice mode on the browser’s Android app to chat about the information in your tabs, as well as ask Perplexity to generate summaries of what you’re seeing.
Shah notes that you can still use Android’s password manager with the browser, though.

title: Know a startup using AI to change the future of work? We'd like to hear from you.
summary:
lighning bolt icon An icon in the shape of a lightning bolt.
lighning bolt icon An icon in the shape of a lightning bolt.
Impact LinkAI has affected nearly every aspect of the workplace.
Business Insider is looking for the most compelling startups transforming how work gets done.
Criteria and methodology:Prospective companies must be startups that use AI to improve some aspect of the workplace — whether in finance, tech, professional services, retail, or transportation.

title: Microsoft’s new Anthropic partnership brings Claude AI models to Azure
summary:
Microsoft is announcing a strategic partnership with Anthropic today that will bring the AI startup’s models to Microsoft Foundry for the first time.
Nvidia and Anthropic are also partnering today as part of this deal, to optimize Anthropic’s models for the best performance on future Nvidia architectures.
The new deal with OpenAI extends Microsoft’s IP rights to models from OpenAI through 2032 and also includes post-AGI (artificial general intelligence) models.
In fact, Microsoft has been favoring Anthropic’s Claude 4 over GPT-5 in its new auto AI model selector in Visual Studio Code.
Microsoft also brought Anthropic’s Claude Sonnet 4 and Claude Opus 4.1 to Microsoft 365 Copilot users recently.

title: AR startup Viture is stealthily working on new AI glasses
summary:
But Vonderful isn’t starting from scratch: Vonder appears to be a stealth project of Viture, an AR startup that has been building glasses since 2021.
Viture isn’t the only AR startup looking to expand from visor-style glasses with birdbath optics to more full-fledged all-in-one devices.
Viture competitor Rokid recently completed a Kickstarter campaign for its own smart glasses, which feature monochrome displays in both lenses.
The company also just unveiled a set of glasses without displays that more closely mimics Meta’s popular Ray-Ban smart glasses.
And TCL offshoot RayNeo launched a first pair of standalone AR glasses in 2024.

title: The FCC is rolling back steps meant to stop a repeat of a massive telecom hack
summary:
After one of the biggest telecom hacks in US history, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) moved to enforce strict standards on carriers’ cybersecurity measures.
The China-linked Salt Typhoon hack revealed last year impacted telecom companies including AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile, and Lumen Technologies, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Now, the FCC under Republican Chair Brendan Carr is rolling back those actions amid a broader deregulation push.
“When I received this draft order, it was very disappointing because we are going to reverse the only meaningful effort this agency has advanced in response to that hack,” Gomez said.
“My fear is Americans will be less secure from the day this hack was discovered a little over a year ago,” she said.

title: The DoorDash problem arrives for Amazon
summary:

Now, it’s time for us to really dive deep into the DoorDash problem.

I don’t know how the industry solves the DoorDash problem.

title: Here’s the Trump executive order that would ban state AI laws
summary:
In recent days, Trump has repeatedly posted his desire to have a state AI law moratorium, and reiterated it on Wednesday during his appearance at the US-Saudi Investment Forum, couching it as a way to fight “woke” ideology.
Because you’ll have one woke state and you’ll have to do all woke.
During an appearance at Politico’s AI & Tech Summit in September, FCC Chairman Brendan Carr floated one potential interpretation of the Communications Act that would allow them to override state law.
He cited the European Union’s Digital Services Act and raised his concern “their AI models are not going to be truth-seeking AI models, but they’re going to be woke AI models, going to be AI models that are promoting DEI.
And so again, President Trump has, as part of his action plan, steps to make sure that we don’t have that type of woke DEI embedded AI models developing here.

title: The drone war is moving too fast for old-school defense tech development, CEO warns
summary:
Roman PILIPEY / AFPDrones — and ways to defeat them — are evolving far too quickly for traditional weapons development cycles, a company making counter-drone systems said.
A rapidly changing drone warThat rapid pace means that it's no longer sufficient to offer solutions that only fix the current problem.
Ukraine and Russia have both been moving very quickly to develop and invest in counter-drone systems, including interceptor drones and AI-powered turrets designed to shoot down drones.
The race to field new drone tech and weapons to defeat them is relentless in this war.
He said drone tech "iterates every two to three weeks on the front line" with a "fundamentally different" model.

title: Chinese University Collected More AI Patents Than MIT, Stanford, Princeton and Harvard Combined
summary: Catch up on stories from the past week (and beyond) at the Slashdot story archive

title: How Generative AI Is Reshaping Venture Capital
summary:
The venture capital world has witnessed countless technological disruptions over the decades, but few have arrived with the speed and scope of generative artificial intelligence.
In the three years since ChatGPT’s launch, gen AI has fundamentally altered how startups are conceived, pitched, built, and funded.
According to a report from Stanford, global private AI investment reached a record high of $252.3 billion in 2024, with generative AI funding soaring to $33.9 billion—more than eight times higher than 2022 levels.

title: Africa's Next Leap in Global Innovation
summary: Emmanuel Lubanzadio of OpenAI, Chris Maurice of Yellow Card and Lexi Novitske of Norrsken22 discuss how AI, blockchain and fintech innovation are positioning Africa at the forefront of global tech advancement with Bloomberg's Yinka Ibukun at Bloomberg Africa Business Summit 2025 in Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: As Windows turns 40, Microsoft faces an AI backlash
summary:
Windows 8 was arguably the most divisive release of Windows in its 40-year history, as Microsoft attempted to overhaul the operating system for a touch-first future.
For some Windows users, it’s already all too much.
It’s this reliable tool that Microsoft seems to want to reshape into something autonomous, increasingly built for AI agents instead of humans.
“We are making this accessible so every user can use [AI agents] when they’re ready.
That’s always been a challenge in Redmond, and often why every other release of the operating system is disliked by so many.

title: Google Gemini is getting better at identifying AI fakes
summary:
Google is making it easier for Gemini users to detect at least some AI-generated content.
The more important expansion will come further down the line, when Google extends verification to support industry-wide C2PA content credentials.
Google also announced that images generated by its Nano Banana Pro model, also revealed today, will have C2PA metadata embedded.
It’s the second bit of good news for C2PA this week, after TikTok confirmed it would use C2PA metadata as part of its own invisible watermarking for AI-generated content.
Manual content verification in Gemini is a useful step, but C2PA credentials, and other watermarks like SynthID, won’t be truly useful until social media platforms get better at flagging AI-generated content automatically, rather than putting the onus on users to confirm for themselves.

title: TikTok is letting users control how much AI content they see
summary:
TikTok is testing a new control that will let users manage how much AI-generated content appears in their video feed on the app.
To help make the filter more effective, the app will also soon start adding invisible watermarks to AI content.
Just like those sliders, the AI control will allow users to request to see more or less AI material, with two levels in either direction.
An AI slider will only work if TikTok itself knows which content is made with AI, so it’s working on improving detection too.
TikTok says both changes are rolling out over “the coming weeks,” though the AI content control is only a test for now.

title: AI agents are invading your PC
summary:
Posts from this author will be added to your daily email digest and your homepage feed.
For a long, long time, Windows looked like Windows.
With Windows 8, Microsoft tried to completely change things… and we know how that went over.
To hear Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella tell it, you may not even use your own computer for long!
And so it is putting agents in every nook and cranny of Windows, starting with the taskbar.

title: AI, my unexpected daily travel companion
summary:
I was starting to doubt it would ever happen, but I finally found a regular, helpful use for AI: vanlife travel planner.
So far, the AI results we’ve gotten have been highly reliable.
Screengrab: GeminiThis type of response goes far beyond anything Google search can produce — even its AI Overview summaries lack weather integration.
The best Google search could do was confirm that yes, people kitesurf in Noli.
I had been dubious about AI’s ability to benefit my day-to-day life prior to using it as a travel companion.
